speaker: Emily Ryan
transcript: George I think you just hit something I was going to bring up is we keep talking about tutorials where the theorists would teach the experimentalists but I think it has to be both ways. It's not that suddenly experimentalists have to learn the theory nor that theory knows everything. I think it has to be more this conversation we're trying to have here of what do you need what can you give us and what can we give you. So the tutorial idea makes me at least in my mind it makes me a little uneasy because as we were just saying it's definitely not down to the level of these are the tools and this is how you use them. It's just more of a conversation between everybody of what are the challenges what do we need to know what can you measure what can't you measure what can you compute what can't you compute you know that's what you're really talking about.

Evaluation & Feedback.explanation: Emily critiques the current framing of 'tutorials' as one-way teaching, stating it makes her 'uneasy' and arguing it needs to be 'both ways' rather than just teaching tools.

Idea Generation & Development.score_justification: The idea is novel in its framing (moving beyond one-way tutorials), highly relevant to the discussion, and elaborated with specific, concrete examples of questions for this collaborative conversation.

speaker: George Shields
transcript: No that's exactly right. And so the problem that most theoreticians have when they read experimental papers is they don't know what the error bars are. And a lot of times experimentalists I was trained as an experimentalist so I started out life as an experimentalist sometimes we don't put our error bars we don't make it really prominent because we're trying to show our work off in the best light. It's a mistake. I mean because you need to know whether you've got an overlap between the theory and the experiment so that you know that you're you have confidence that you're basically getting it and what your error bars are when you do a simulation or whatever it is. So I agree completely. I mean it's got to be a two-way street and people need to know what are the best ways to look at these things experimentally and how do you trust your data.

speaker: Matt Green
transcript: One idea I have or one problem I see is we still we keep thinking about capture and conversion or storage as two separate ideas. You know you do your capture and then you feed whatever you captured off to some other process. I think that that could be a really interesting area for experimentalists and theorists and systems designs to all converge on one new unique problem.
